title: R-Ladies Lancaster Launch!
description:
R-Ladies Lancaster is ready to announce our first event!

Our launch event will include a number of talks about R, and there will also be plenty of time for networking over pizza! (Big thank you to H20.ai for sponsoring the pizza at our launch event).

Schedule:

18:00 - 18:20: Registration
18:20 - 18:30: Introduction to R-Ladies and the local groups
18:30 - 18:50: Nic Crane: Ten Steps to Becoming a Tidyverse Contributor
18:50 - 19:20: Pizza break/networking
19:20 - 19:40: Rhian Davies: A day in the life with R. A whirlwind tour.
19:40 - 20:00: Lucy Morgan: The rocky road to building my first R package
20:00 - 20:30 Networking/close

Nic Crane (Elucidata): 10 Steps to Becoming a Tidyverse Contributor
In 2018 I became a contributor to the tidyverse and realised that you don't have to be an R expert to get involved. In this talk, I will discuss why I was originally hesitant to contribute to open source, but how the R community made me realise my doubts were unfounded. I'll walk you through the stages of making a pull request to a tidyverse package and discuss my experiences of doing so. Whilst the focus of this talk is on contributing code, I conclude with the other valuable ways you can get involved, whether you've been using R for 2 weeks or 20 years. I'd love to make this talk interactive, so please bring any questions you have!

Rhian Davies (Jumping Rivers): A day in the life with R.
I've been using R for many years and at the moment it feels like I basically run my life in the medium of R. I'll give an whirlwind tour of a day in my life as an analyst and all the weird and wonderful ways R helps - and hinders.

Lucy Morgan (Lancaster University): The rocky road to building my first R package
I heard that putting an R package together was simple once you had functions that worked. I must have heard wrong. In this talk Iâ€™ll discuss a few of the difficulties I had in starting to build my first R package (you can then avoid these). Iâ€™ll also add a few tips from the package building process and demonstrate building a very simple package in R.

*** Venue ***

We're meeting in Room A076 of the Science & Technology building. This might be tricky to find, but there will be plenty of signs up. You can download a campus map:

https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_lancaster/blob/master/admin/campus-map.pdf.

The star represents the room we will be in, and I have highlighted the main entrances to the building. Note that building is locked after 6pm. We will be around the main entrances from 6:00pm - 6:20pm to greet you and let you in, so please try to arrive promptly! If you are running late, please ring me (07805 871708) and we'll come and let you in.

If you need more or advice help finding the location, please get in touch.

Parking:
Parking is free on the University campus after 6pm. The closest place to park is Fylde Avenue or George Fox Avenue.

There are also very frequent buses to the University and an excellent cycle route.

---

R-Ladies Lancaster is part of a global initiative, R-Ladies Global, designed to improve the gender diversity of R users worldwide and in particular, to improve the participation and experience of women in the R community. As part of the initiative, R-Ladies Lancaster will host a number of talks and workshops about the use of R. It doesn't matter if you never used R or if you are an R expert, R-Ladies Lancaster welcomes anyone with an interest in R.

Questions? E-mail: rhian@rladies.org

title: Exploring the layers of visualisation- an introduction to ggplot2
description:
Are you one of the R-lovers that always wondered how to (effectively) visualise your data, then this workshop is for you. Together we explore layers of data visualisation: from the theory to the technical implementation in ggplot2. It will be cooked for you by Janine Khuc, Sarah Stolle and Olga Ivanova - three awesome R-Ladies co-organizers.

Big-big thanks to Ubiqum Code Academy for making this event possible!

PRELIMINARY PLAN
18.00-18.30 Doors open & Welcome
18.30- 18.50 Introduction to R-Ladies & Ubiqum
18.50- 19.30- Workshop part 1
19.30- 19.45 Break
19.45- 20.30 Workshop part 2
20.30- 21.00 Socialising

PROGRAMME
Everyone from the data science community wants to produce a beautiful plot that is also convincing, informative and clear enough. This can be a truly challenging task! We will start out with a short introduction on how it all started and think with you about how to do it more properly. But of course, through thinking data visualisations won't create themselves, we need tools to do so effectively!

As such, we will explain and deep dive into the basic concepts of ggplot2 as it is one of the most powerful libraries in R available today for visualization. Weâ€™ll cover the basics step by step, using code examples to explore the datasets. At the end we'll set you free - so you can play around with your newly gained knowledge of ggplot2 and go on to explore data (and the world).

REQUIREMENTS
A basic knowledge of R and an urge to study data vis/ggplot2. Please, bring your own laptop with installed R, R Studio, ggplot2 and tidyr/reshape2.

CODE OF CONDUCT
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: R packages - sharing with others and helping yourself
description: Let's make a package! Javi Rudolph will lead this session and hopefully convince you to make your own R package. A brief introduction to basic package structure coupled with some hands-on exercises and examples will lay the foundation for your package-building journey. Start small with a package for your data analysis, dream big. No prior experience with building R packages is necessary (actually, this is very intro level so if you've built a package before you probably know this). Basic familiarity with R language is helpful.

title: Post-SatRday Chicago R-Ladies Meetup!
description:
Meet up with R-Ladies Chicago after Chicago's first one-day R conference happening at the end of April, SatRday Chicago!

We'll be meeting up at the post-conference happy hour at Roosevelt University. R-Ladies from out of town will be at the event, and we'd like to welcome them :)

Attendance at the conference is not required for *female and non-binary individuals* to join R-Ladies at the happy hour. We encourage our male allies to buy a ticket and attend the conference! Tickets are cheap - $50 for professionals, $25 for students, and the event will feature over 35 speakers (!) and food.

If you're looking for a day of R learning and networking, check out the schedule and get a ticket to SatRday Chicago here: https://chicago2019.satrdays.org/

title: R-Ladies en FLISOL - workshop - charlas
description:
Vamos a realizar un workshop de R-Ladies Mendoza en el marco del FLISOL (Festival Latinoamericano de instalaciÃ³n de software libre), que se realizarÃ¡ en la UTN Mendoza.

Las charlas tratas de diferentes casos de uso y aplicaciones de R y Rstudio.

Cronograma general (podrÃ­an surgir pequeÃ±as modificaciones):

10:00 - 10:30 hs - Bienvenida FLISOL en SalÃ³n de actos, registraciÃ³n

10:30 - 10:45 hs - PresentaciÃ³n de iniciativa R-Ladies
Disertantes: Jan Strappa (Ing. en Sistemas de InformaciÃ³n, becarie Doctoral CONICET, twitter @superXponential), Brenda Canizo (Lic. en BromatologÃ­a, twitter: twitter.com/Brenda_Canizo)

10:45 - 11:30 - Presentaciones con Rmarkdown.
Disertante: Amalia Susana Haye, twitter: @amaliamdz
Breve bio: Profesora en MatemÃ¡ticas, Ã¡rea de interÃ©s: EstadÃ­stica
Contenido de la exposiciÃ³n: Rmarkdown es una herramienta para escribir documentos juntamente con cÃ³digo R. Permite la ejecuciÃ³n de cÃ³digo con la posibilidad de realizar presentaciones y documentaciÃ³n de calidad.

11:30 - 12:05 - EstimaciÃ³n de la evapotranspiraciÃ³n real de vid mediante Modelos de Balance de EnergÃ­a. El paquete â€œwaterâ€ (CRAN).
Disertante: MarÃ­a Victoria MunafÃ³
Breve bio: Ingeniera agrÃ³noma, investigadora, geomÃ¡tica y agricultura de precisiÃ³n, "water" package's contributor.
Contenido de la exposiciÃ³n:
En regiones semiÃ¡ridas, las precipitaciones no son suficientes para cubrir los requerimientos hÃ­dricos de los cultivos. Saber cuÃ¡nto hay que regar es la clave del riego. Se conoce como evapotranspiraciÃ³n (ET) a la combinaciÃ³n de procesos separados por los que el agua se pierde a travÃ©s de la superficie del suelo (evaporaciÃ³n) y por la transpiraciÃ³n del cultivo.
Se presenta el paquete "water" disponible en el repositorio CRAN desde el aÃ±o 2016. Provee muchas funciones para estimar los parÃ¡metros de la ecuaciones de ET desde imÃ¡genes satelitales. Propone una nueva clase de objeto para manipular los datos de estaciones meteorolÃ³gicas (waterWeatherStation) y resuelve mediante un mÃ©todo automÃ¡tico, uno de los puntos crÃ­ticos del modelo METRIC (Mapping EvapoTranspiration at high Resolution with Internalized Calibration).

12:05 - 12:25 - OptimizaciÃ³n de la selecciÃ³n de sitios de muestreo en la vitivinicultura mediante anÃ¡lisis multiescalar de imÃ¡genes satelitales de NDVI.
Disertante: Julieta Dalmasso
Breve bio: Ingeniera agrÃ³noma con interÃ©s en recursos hÃ­dricos y geomÃ¡tica.
Contenido de la exposiciÃ³n: Se presenta un caso de estudio de analizar imÃ¡genes satelitales de una finca de vid en espaldero (Vitis vinifera cv. Cabernet sauvignon), ubicado en la localidad de Ugarteche, LujÃ¡n de Cuyo, Mendoza. Se aplicÃ³ un anÃ¡lisis multiescalar, mediante la utilizaciÃ³n de imÃ¡genes satelitales Lansat 8 y Sentinel 2 de alta resoluciÃ³n espacial. El trabajo permitiÃ³ aplicar una metodologÃ­a para identificar Ã¡reas homogÃ©neas segÃºn el Ã­ndice de vegetaciÃ³n (NVDI) presentes en el predio. La incorporaciÃ³n de esta metodologÃ­a para la selecciÃ³n de sitios de muestreo anÃ¡logos en predios de grandes superficies, hacen de esta herramienta informÃ¡tica un producto viable, accesible, de bajo costo y reproducible en cualquier Ã¡mbito.

12:25 - 13:00 - R en genÃ©tica - ClusterizaciÃ³n de haplotipos
Disertante: Tatiana SofÃ­a Parlanti
Breve bio: Estudiante avanzada de la carrera Licenciatura en Ciencias BÃ¡sicas con orientaciÃ³n en MatemÃ¡tica, de la FCEN-UNCUYO.
Contenido de la exposiciÃ³n:
En los Ãºltimos aÃ±os se ha incrementado el uso del mapeo asociativo, herramienta estadÃ­stica que permite identificar regiones especÃ­ficas del genoma relacionadas con la variaciÃ³n de un carÃ¡cter fenotÃ­pico de interÃ©s, como estrategia para identificar QTL. El objetivo de este proyecto fue mejorar tÃ©cnicas computacionales aplicadas a las matrices asociadas a distintas poblaciones de mapeo vinculadas con los programas de mejoramiento de arroz y soja. Se usÃ³ el paquete clusterhap para el anÃ¡lisis.

title: Data4good hackathon
description:
The First data4good Hackathon In collaboration with the Vienna Data Science Group and WeAreDevelopers::Keep-Current will take place in the last weekend of April!

Are you looking to use your skills, knowledge or interest in data for good? Then join us in our first data4good Hackathon, for two days of pure coding & fun while doing something good on the way -- Be a part of the change you want to see in the world of data!

We seek all data enthusiasts:
aspiring data scientists or experienced data wizards; savvy solvers of business intelligence requests; machine learning pros, predictive analytics angels, data mining experts, computer vision idealists, UX maestros and ambitious developers with an interest in social causesâ€¦

Let's help together GruenStattGrau, Hilfswerk Ã–sterreich, Hilfswerk International & CivesSolutions in their quest.

title: Monthly R Ladies Meeting: Exploring caret
description:
Want to hone your machine learning skills? Fiona Lodge will guide us through her adventures with the caret package! ("caret" is short for Classificiation And REgression.) This will be a hands-on working session, so please bring a laptop.

If you want to be ready for action:
-Install the caret package in R using install.packages(â€œcaretâ€Â­)

CONSUMING THINGS:
Just down the hall is a mini coffee shop. Feel free to bring dinner, snackies, or beverages from home.

LOCATION:
Meet us in room 226 of O'Shaughnessy Science (OSS). This is connected to Owens and is part of the Frey Science Center (big cement sign out front). OSS is on the west side of Cretin between Grand and Summit. The east side of the building has an elevator, and the building is ADA accessible.

PARKING:
Street parking on Summit is free but limited. The parking ramp (on Grand and Cretin) is very close to OSS and is decently priced ($1.00 per hour).

title: Applications of R: From detecting marine heatwaves to mapping out school data
description:
Join us for two talks showcasing some of the applications of what you can do with R!

### Amieroh Abrahams: "Detecting marine heatwaves (MHWs) by using R-programming"

Over the past three decades, anthropologically mediated warming has negatively affected marine and terrestrial ecosystems. This has ultimately resulted in major consequences for humanity and natural ecological functioning. Climate change is generally understood as the long-term rise in global mean surface temperatures. Recent studies have shown an increase in the frequency of extreme events. Extreme warming events such as marine heatwaves (MHW) are defined as a discrete prolonged anomalously warm water event. Here I will demonstrate the various R packages produced and utilized by South African scientists (heatwaveR and RmarineHeatWaves) to detect these extreme events.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Megan Beckett: "Exploring the South African School Directory with R"

South Africa has an incredibly diverse, expansive education system, with over *25 000* schools dotted across the country, ranging from dilapidated mud huts and blackboards underneath trees to state-of-the-art, high tech facilities.

I wanted to see how I could add value by taking some seemingly forgotten Excel files from the Department of Basic Education website, and providing a visual map to explore, understand and appreciate the diversity and complexity of our education system.

Iâ€™ll show how I used *OpenStreetMaps* to help geocode missing data for school locations, and then used *Shiny* and *Leaflet* to create an app which allows anybody to visually explore, understand and locate schools across our country, without having to delve into those enormous Excel files.

By the end, not only will you get an idea of how easy it is to turn legacy geospatial data into something visual, interactive and informative, but youâ€™ll also have a unique perspective into the challenges posed by South Africaâ€™s multifarious, multilayered, multicultural and multicoloured education system.

title: RMarkdown and Bookdown for Dissertating
description:
This month's meet up, led by Thea Knowles, will be an interactive tutorial on preparing to write a dissertation using RMarkdown and Bookdown.

RMarkdown allows you to seamlessly integrate R code and narrative text as well as specify formatting options across multiple document output types (docx, pdf, html). Bookdown serves as a means to combining multiple RMarkdown files into a final book*.

This workshop will feature a crash course on RMarkdown and will cover the following: reference management in RMarkdown, tips for a modular workflow, integrating templates (like Western's thesis templates) into RMarkdown/bookdown documents, and more.

And yes, yes this can totally count as writing time.

*"Despite the package name containing the word â€œbookâ€, bookdown is not only for books. The â€œbookâ€ can be anything that consists of multiple R Markdown documents meant to be read in a linear sequence, such as course handouts, study notes, a software manual, a thesis, or even a diary." - Yihui Xie https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/

title: R Under The Hood
description: Hi everyone! Apologies for the radio silence, many of us have been traveling. We'd like to host our next RLadies Meetup at the Sherman Fairchild Library at Caltech on Wednesday, April 24th, at 6pm. The topic will be "R Under The Hood" led by Gail Clement, and will cover project setup configurations, including how to customize your .Rprofile and .Renvironment files. We'll have food at 6, and the presentation will start at 7. Hope to see you there!

title: #tidytuesday Work Group + Farewell to Mine
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! Work individually or with the group and end the evening by sharing your work.

We will explore the comic book characters #tidytuesday data set: https://bit.ly/2UcQ9f8. You can read more about the data and the fivethirtyeight.com article it's presented in here: https://bit.ly/2jMRt2S.

We will also be celebrating all the hard work Mine has done to start and build R-Ladies RTP! Please join us in wishing her best of luck as she starts her new position in Edinburgh, Scotland.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:30 pm #tidytuesday
7:30 - 8:00 pm Discussion + Celebration

This is a great opportunity to meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build up your GitHub/Twitter/data science portfolio!

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together!

What should I bring?
Please bring your own laptop (fully-charged!) and all learning materials you want to use. If you have time, please look at the data set beforehand and think about some questions you'd like to answer with it.

Where will it take place?
Cocoa Cinnamon Lakewood

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: RLadies Presents: Twitter Analysis in R
description:
* Note - this is an R-Ladies Sydney Event. We welcome all attendees. We draw your attention to the R-Ladies Global guidelines and code of conduct (https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).*

Twitter is a microblogging site with 100 million active daily users who post 500 million tweets per day, creating a free and readily accessible dataset that can be analysed to ask questions from social science to consumer behaviour and beyond.

At this event, Dr Khandis Blake will walk through the process of extracting and analysing data from Twitter. After demonstrating how to extract tweets using the Twitter API, Khandis will explain how to geolocate tweets using string matches and collect assign gender to users. She will also go through the basics of parallel processing. Attendees will learn how to use parallel, streamR, twitteR, ROAuth, ndjson, stringr, and stringi.

This event is appropriate for R users at all levels of experience, and geared towards those who are beginners in terms of using R for Twitter data analysis. You do not need to have a Twitter account.

This event is appropriate for R users at all levels of experience, and geared towards those who are beginners in terms of using R for Twitter data analysis. You do not need to have a Twitter account.

Please arrive at 6pm for time to connect with other attendees before a 6:30 start.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

It's not inherently a code-along workshop, but if you want to have a go with the R code that Khandis will share, you'll need to set up a few things ahead of time - and of course bring your laptop to the event!

1. Get a Twitter API account: https://towardsdatascience.com/access-data-from-twitter-api-using-r-and-or-python-b8ac342d3efe [do this sooner than later! our approval process took a while to come through, but that could have been because we indicated 'organisation use']

2. Set up an App: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rtweet/vignettes/auth.html

With the tokens and authorization in place, you'll be able to grab data from twitter via your own account!

title: Data Visualization with Maps Shiny Workshop
description:
Learn how to make your first Shiny app with spatial data! We'll build a simple interactive map application and teach you how to use Shiny apps to interpret and visualize your data.

â€¢ What you'll learn:

- Why build a Shiny app?
- How a Shiny app is structured
- How to incorporate interactivity in your Shiny app
- How to deploy your Shiny app

â€¢ Prerequisites:

-William Blair has a strict firewall, so please follow the instructions here prior to the Meetup so that you are able to get the most out of this workshop: https://github.com/rladies-chicago/2019-04-18-shiny-workshop/blob/master/README.md

-If your Meetup profile does not include your first name, please email chicago@rladies.org with the subject line "Name for 4/18 Meetup" and your name in the body of the email so we can make sure you are on the list of approved guests.

6-6:30 -- Food, Intros & Announcements

Q: Are men welcome to attend this event?
A: Our primary mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. ***As such, we strongly encourage that all men who attend this event have a female or non-binary sponsor. Please contact chicago@rladies.org if you have questions.***

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

Thank you to William Blair for hosting us and providing food!

title: The tidyverse special edition. Workshop.
description:
Welcome!

We are starting this season with a workshop to boost your skills in R!

We will go through the essentials of the tidyverse packages, covering functions that will help you transform and clean a raw dataset to packages that will help you communicate your results with beautiful graphs and tables!

Doesn't matter if you are a beginner or if you are an R expert, this workshop is for everyone!

For this workshop please bring your laptop with R and Rstudio installed.
We will use the following packages: tidyverse and kableExtra.
Scrips and presentation will be announced and provided before the meetup in the following link: https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_rotterdam.

title: Hierarchical and Partitioning clustering in R
description:
Blythe Moreland will go through some of the faster methods for hierarchical and partitioning clustering and then spend some time on network visualization, such as igraph or visNetwork.

Blythe is a post-doctoral scientist working in the translational bioinformatics group at the Institute for Genomic Medicine at Nationwide Children's Hospital. She works with biologists, informatics analysts, and computer scientists, in part to study how genetic variants can indirectly affect protein formation or protein binding, and be linked to human diseases.

Materials will be available on R-Ladies github under meetup presentations repo of our chapter (https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_columbus) on the day of the meetup.

Can access the RStudio Cloud portion here: https://rstudio.cloud/project/312108

Please bring your laptop and have R and RStudio (and the tidyverse package) installed and working. But if things don't work and you're having issues, don't worry! We're here to help (â—•â€¿â—•âœ¿)

And we'll have pizza! ğŸ•

Parking: Park in any spot marked "Reserved for the Columbus Collaboratory". There should be more than enough available- all are free. If you find that these spots are filled - park anywhere in surrounding lots and Katie will give you a day pass for your dashboard.

Call Katie if any issues finding it (440-452-6423).
Directions and map also available here:
http://columbuscollaboratory.com/Contact

title: R + AI Share & Tell
description:
Are you currently working through a Deep Learning or Machine Learning tutorial, course, or project? This Share & Tell roundtable will give you the opportunity to plug in your laptop & share with the rest of the group! It can be any sort of success, failure, or frustration you've experienced on your journey.

The focus of the group is R but given that many libraries are only available in Python or other languages, and it's often easier to just use them instead of making everything work in R, I supposed we'll allow it ;) Just be aware there is a high likelihood the audience will be skewed towards R & scientific research workflows (as opposed to Python & software engineering).

This is a shared event with PDX WiMLDS (https://www.meetup.com/PDX-Women-in-Machine-Learning-and-Data-Science/), you can RSVP in either place.

title: CANCELED! Short hands-on the universe of xaringan, bookdown and blogdown
description:
Dear R-Ladies members and visitors,

the upcoming R-Ladies Berlin meetup is going to be one of a very special kind for me personally. After two years of organising R-Ladies Berlin I have to say goodbye. This meetup is going to be one of my last "official" ones. End of April I am moving to Toulouse, new tasks and challenges are calling.

But before let's have another great R-Ladies Berlin event.

In the first part - the talk - I would like to share with you some insights of the package universe of Yihui Xie, software developer at R-Studio and creator of knitR, blogdown and many more great packages. In my talk I would like to give you brief introductions and hand-ons of three of my favourite ones - xanigan, bookdown and blogdown.
All three packages provide a great implementation of R-Studio for the daily routines of a life as a scientist, student or journalist. Xanigan helps you to create beautiful presentations based on R markdown documents.
Blogdown provides a smooth integration to built your own blog using GitHub and Netifly. The las one bookdown gives you the resources to create documents or even books which are pleasant to read, distribute or even to publish.
I hope to show you the beauty and pleasant handling of these packages to just get you started on your own project. Please, bring your laptop, install these packackes, check your currently installed R-version and bring all your resources that you might already have to share it with the participants.

In the second part of the meetup we would like to code with you altogether, running for the first time a section we call "RetrinkR". Here, we would like to share a piece of code on GitHub and invite you to work with us on it. That might mean another way of data visualisation or how the raw data has been manipulated before hand or any further extensions. Examples of code can be submitted to GitHub and shared with all participants.
After a short introduction we are going to spend not more than an hour to have fun coding, learning and playing with R altogether.

If you have any chunk of code that you think that would be perfectly suitable - you are stuck and need a fresh view - get in touch with us here on meetup.

Also in case of any other questions - please drop us a line at berlin@rladies.org.

I am looking forward - with a smile in one eye and a tear in the other - to the next meetup session and would love to see as many as possible of the great Ladies that I meet during the last two years. Babbel is going to take care of snacks, drinks and provides its beautiful space in Berlin Mitte.

If you cannot make it, I'll keep in touch and stay in the background of R-Ladies Berlin and try to be in town for an event of R-Ladies.

Best regards,
and on behalf of R-Ladies Berlin organisers
Chrissy

title: Open Science and Bioinformatics? April R-Ladies & DataPhilly event
description:
Please join us April 16th to learn about the open science movement and how it is impacting the traditionally closed world of biology research. We are excited to be hosting Olga Botvinnik â€“ a bioinformatics scientist and advocate for open data and open science. She will be sharing some insights from her research and also her career experiences more generally.

This event is a collaboration between R-Ladies Philly and DataPhilly - no background in bioinformatics is needed!

==Estimated Agenda==
6:00: Food and casual networking (refreshments generously provided by Vistar Media)
6:30: Intro to the Childhood Cancer Data Lab by Jaclyn Taroni, PhD
6:45: "If I wasn't such a mess" by Olga Botvinnik, PhD - followed by time for Q&A and additional conversations

Olga Botvinnik is a bioinformatics scientist at Chan Zuckerberg Biohub, a non-profit biomedical research institute. She is a genomics expert interested in a â€œgrand unified theory of cells,â€ by applying computer science and machine learning algorithms to biological data, especially interested in sequencing weird creatures such as ticks. She holds two S.B. degrees, one in Mathematics and one in Biological Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She also holds a M.S. in Bioinformatics and Biomolecular Engineering from UC Santa Cruz, and she completed her education with a PhD in Bioinformatics and Systems Biology from UC San Diego. She is a NumFOCUS John Hunter Technical Fellowship and NDSEG Fellowship recipient. She runs a weekly Twitch livestreaming channel called â€œBioinformatics Beyonceâ€ that showcases real bioinformatics work such as genome assembly, open-source software and cloud computing, and interviews with scientists about their research and day-to-day work. Open science, open data, open source.

Jaclyn Taroni, PhD is a data scientist at the Childhood Cancer Data Lab, an Alexâ€™s Lemonade Stand Foundation initiative located right here in Philadelphia (https://www.ccdatalab.org). The CCDL supports open science and specifically cancer research by creating tools to make biological big data easier to access, mine, and reuse.

==Getting there==
The event is hosted by our friends at Azavea â€“ 990 Spring Garden St. You can enter via the north side of the building where there is a security guard. Take the elevator to the 5th floor. For public transit and other information about the building: https://www.azavea.com/directions/

==About our sponsors==
Vistar Media: On the Vistar Media engineering team, we never stop looking for our next addition. Weâ€™re kinda hoping that addition is you. We are located in Old City, Philadelphia.
We're a startup with an established, well-tested codebase, but we aren't afraid to shake things up. We want to solve our problems with the right tools, whether theyâ€™re cutting-edge, or tried-and-true. We're happy to explore new territory (who isn't?), but we won't jump on something shiny for the sake of it. Our engineers work with many different languages and platforms every day. If this gets you excited, we'd love to hear from you. https://www.vistarmedia.com/open-positions

Azavea is a B Corporation that creates civic geospatial software for the web. We build custom application; develop data analytics; and manage several open source projects (GeoTrellis, Raster Vision, Raster Foundry, and others). All of our work is aimed at advancing the state of the art in geospatial technology and applying it for civic, social, and environmental impact. We work in many domains, including: elections, planning, water, transportation, climate change and land conservation.
Azavea is currently recruiting for an Operations Engineer (more at https://careers.azavea.com/) as well as for two fellowship programs, Summer of Maps and our Open Source Fellowship.

title: Reflections from an R Lady in the Untidyverse of Cancer Research
description:
Welcome to our first event! It's free!

R-Ladies Lyon is pleased to welcome Dr. Hilary Robbins, scientist at the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC/WHO) in Lyon, France.

Her research develops and applies risk-based approaches to cancer screening, with a current focus on lung cancer screening.

Dr. Robbins will give a brief overview of her career thus far in cancer research, including how R fits into her profile as a researcher. She will discuss how she came to use R, an application from her current research (predicting risk of lung cancer during CT screening), some tips and tricks with her favorite tidyverse packages, and a few reflections about being an R lady in a male-dominated field.

Presenter: Dr. Hilary Robbins
Title: Reflections from an R Lady in the Untidyverse of Cancer Research
Twitter: @hilaryarobbins
https://www.linkedin.com/in/hilary-robbins-6a840223/
https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=ehL9SRcAAAAJ&hl=en

The talk will be held in English but you can ask your questions in French and we will help you translate. R-Ladies offers a platform for women to present their work and everyone is welcome to attend! Pizza and drinks will be provided after the presentation.

Follow us on twitter! @RLadiesLyon

title: Transition to Data Science
description:
Join PyLadies, R-Ladies, Women in Data Science (WiDS), and Insight Data Science to learn about transitioning to a career in data science and the variety of roles that full under the title 'data scientist'!

To help us plan, please RSVP directly on the WiDS meetup page:
http://meetu.ps/e/GBzH9/GRKLB/f

We'll start with lightning talks from panelists on what their job as a data scientist entails, which will be followed by a panel discussion focused on how the panelists moved into the field and their experiences in it. There will, of course, be plenty of time for questions from attendees!

Panelists include:
- Lisa Qian
Data Science Manager at Airbnb, transitioned to DS 6 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/lisa-qian-98b04326/
- Annette Taberner-Miller
Data Science Manager at Indeed, transitioned to DS 8 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/annette-taberner-miller/
- Susan Fung
Sr. Data Analyst at Liberty Mutual, transitioned to DS 1 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/susanfung/
- Nupur Mehta
Data Scientist II at Redfin, transitioned to DS 2 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/nupurmehta4/
- Gina Schmalzle
Senior Data Scientist at Nordstrom, transitioned to DS 4 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/ginaschmalzle/
- Heather Nolis
Machine Learning Engineer at T-Mobile, transitioned to DS 1 yr ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/heatherwensler/

Many thanks to Insight Data Science for sponsoring this event!

Schedule:
6:15-6:45: arrive, pizza, drinks
6:45-7:15: lightning talks on what data scientist jobs can include
7:15-8: panel
8-8:30: networking

title: R Lunch and Learn
description: What's better than R? R plus lunch, of course! Bring your coding questions/concerns/ideas and your laptop to lunch with your fellow R Ladies. We hope to see you there!

title: Kick-off meeting R-Ladies Frankfurt
description:
Dear all,

Thanks for joining R-Ladies Frankfurt group!

We're happy to invite you to the first meetup on 12th April (Friday).

This meeting is to:
(1) Present R-Ladies and the motivation to create R-Ladies in Frankfurt
(2) Get to know each other
(3) Discuss topics that you are interested to learn, your expectations about the group, and options to get involved with R-Ladies Frankfurt
(4) R-Ladies code of conduct

This event intends to connect the R-Ladies community in Frankfurt (no matter if you are a complete newbie to R, intermediate or professional R-user) in an informal environment. For that, the idea is to meet for coffee, cake, and networking in a coffeehouse in Frankfurt.

Location:
36 Grad
Oppenheimer LandstraÃŸe 36
(Schweizer Platz)
60596 Frankfurt

What to bring?
Ideas and motivation to brainstorm, meet people, and have fun to create an active R community for women!

In the meantime, please fill in the following survey to get an idea of your interests and skill-level: https://forms.gle/Afn6U6qvekNxYaLL9 Feel free to fill out the survey even if you cannot make it to the meeting, as this is important to pick speakers and topics that are of most interest to you in future meetings!

If you have any suggestions/questions, please feel free to get in touch: frankfurt@rladies.org

Also, follow R-Ladies Frankfurt on twitter: @RLadiesFRA (https://twitter.com/RLadiesFRA) and stay tuned for R and R-Ladies related tweets!

Know other people interested in R? Bring them along!
Please only RSVP if you can come!

Looking forward to meeting you!

Sandra

title: Workshop - Introduction to R
description:
Dear all,

The goal of our next meetup is for our attendees to become acquainted with R and R Studio in order to start their data analytics journey.

We'll cover:

* Brief intro to R as a programming language
* Functions, data structures, data types
* Reading data into R
* Basic data visualization in R
* R packages
* Examples and use cases

If time allows we will briefly introduce to you Rmarkdown and give a glimpse into how to make your analysis more reproducible.

We recommend you bring your own laptop where you have
R and RStudio installed (https://cran.r-project.org/ and https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/).
In case you want to install Rmarkdown you can follow the instructions at https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown/installation.html

See you soon!

venues.name: Vienna University of Economics and Business

title: April is Shiny!
description:
Spring is here! That means this month is all about all things Shiny (if that makes sense)!

We have two speakers who are regulars on the R-Ladies Copenhagen circuit, Diana Lucatero and Ivana Hybenova. Special thanks go to Deloitte Risk Advisory for sponsoring this event!

Talk 1: Data science- from academia to industry
On this lighting talk, Diana will share her experience deploying advanced analytics in academia & industry with the main focus being the differences in communication & security considerations. The talk will include:
(1) A very introductory sketch of shiny (what it is and why)
(2) A hands on demonstration of how you can build & deploy a simple web app.
(3) A 10 min exploration session of some cool interactive visualizations.
(4) A demonstration on how you can install R packages in a secure manner (it's all about risk, risk!).

Diana is a data science consultant in Deloitte Risk Advisory. She has experience with advanced analytics in environmental science & now she is applying her knowledge in the field of risk analytics. In the old days, she was a Matlab junkie, but now she has learned her lesson & joined the shiny-dark-R-side!

Talk 2: Using Shiny to troubleshoot machine learning tasks
In this talk, Ivana will show us how to use R Shiny to solve a machine learning task quicker!

She has built an app that loads in a cleaned dataset and train several regression models: linear, support vector machine (SVM), random forest for regression, and generalized boosted regression.

We will even tune the algorithms from within the app, where Ivana will demonstrate the app and review the code. Even if you have not tried to 'machine-learn' yourself, it is one more reason to join as it will be super easy to perform and understand!

Shiny experts: Be aware that this talk is introductory. You're of course welcome to join, you'll have fun anyway!

Details:
When: April 11th
Where: Deloitte Horizon
Time: 17:30 - 20:00

What to bring: laptop with RStudio installed. We will give you more details soon on which packages you will need in case you would like to code during the session.

Snacks, drinks and sandwiches will be provided. See you all soon!

Regards,
RLadies CPH
Kristina, Lei, Diana

title: Processing large datasets using R
description:
Kia ora koutou!

We are very excited to have Elaine Miles from Aeroqual LTD speaking at R-Ladies Auckland.

Arrive at 6pm for a 6:30pm start.

# Speaker details

Elaine Miles is a data scientist based in Auckland. She works at Aeroqual LTD where she uses machine learning methods to analyse and improve the operation of air quality sensors and networks. She previously worked at the Australian Bureau of Meteorology on large seasonal models to predict extreme sea levels, and to test the impact of observation networks to weather prediction models. Her PhD focused on adapting laser-based methods to monitor artwork (which included watching paint dry).

Elaine has recently learnt how to program in R and is going to share some of her insights on working with multiple processors in order to crunch large datasets and execute repetitive tasks in parallel.

title: satRdays at UCLA - anyone up for a Road Trip?
description:
Hey R-Ladies!

SatRdays are a locally organized, low cost, R conferences. They happen all over the world and we have one coming to LA on April 6th! Even more, Erin LeDell, of R-Ladies Global, is keynoting so there is some special R-Ladies flare in this one.

Reg is $35 ($15 for students!) and the agenda is AWESOME. Lots of data science, but also making packages, Shiny, and more.

Here's how to register + the agenda: https://losangeles2019.satrdays.org/

Happy to carpool and we'll organize logistics once we get a feel for who is joining us. It'd be an early morning, but we can get coffee. Looking to depart San Diego by 6am.

title: RLadiesDC BooksNBars - Brave, Not Perfect: Fear Less, Fail More, and Live Bolder
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Brave, Not Perfect: Fear Less, Fail More, and Live Bolder by the founder of Girls Who Code.

Purchase the book here: https://www.amazon.com/Brave-Not-Perfect-Fear-Bolder/dp/1524762334/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1549747438&sr=8-1&keywords=brave+not+perfect

In a book inspired by her popular TED talk, New York Times bestselling author Reshma Saujani empowers women and girls to embrace imperfection and bravery. Watch the TED talk here: https://www.ted.com/talks/reshma_saujani_teach_girls_bravery_not_perfection?language=en#t-743449

Imagine if you lived without the fear of not being good enough. If you didn't care how your life looked on Instagram, or worry about what total strangers thought of you. Imagine if you could let go of the guilt, and stop beating yourself up for tiny mistakes. What if, in every decision you faced, you took the bolder path?

Too many of us feel crushed under the weight of our own expectations. We run ourselves ragged trying to please everyone, all the time. We lose sleep ruminating about whether we may have offended someone, pass up opportunities that take us out of our comfort zones, and avoid rejection at all costs.

There's a reason we act this way, Reshma says. As girls, we were taught to play it safe. Well-meaning parents and teachers praised us for being quiet and polite, urged us to be careful so we didn't get hurt, and steered us to activities at which we could shine.

The problem is that perfect girls grow up to be women who are afraid to fail. It's time to stop letting our fears drown out our dreams and narrow our world, along with our chance at happiness.

By choosing bravery over perfection, we can find the power to claim our voice, to leave behind what makes us unhappy, and go for the things we genuinely, passionately want. Perfection may set us on a path that feels safe, but bravery leads us to the one we're authentically meant to follow.

In Brave, Not Perfect, Reshma shares powerful insights and practices to help us override our perfect girl training and make bravery a lifelong habit. By being brave, not perfect, we can all become the authors of our biggest, boldest, and most joyful life.

PS Please contact the organizer if you lack the funds to purchase the book.

title: Open Challenges in a Data Science Team
description:
We are delighted to invite you to a special event called â€œOpen Challenges in a Data Science Teamâ€ sponsored by Prometeia.
In this meeting Prometeia will present two important use-cases and challenges that any Data Science team can face:
- How to create an advanced analytics center of excellence
- How to extract value from unstructured data

How to create an advanced analytics center of excellence
Speaker: Mariapia Lampis, Business translator at Prometeia
In order to gain competitive advantages, data-driven companies should govern and value the informative heritage collected on clients and companies. By applying innovative strategies and methodologies on those data, companies optimize the decisional and operational processes, develop new products and business models. In this talk, Mariapia will describe how Prometeia Data Science team supports the set-up and training of analytical teams in banks and insurance companies, the identification of organizational structures and the development of a portfolio of analytical projects with high business impact.
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/in/mariapia-lampis-561764102/

How to extract value from unstructured data
Speaker: Oriana Angelucci, Business translator at Prometeia
The Digital disruption has generated a staggering increase in unstructured data that, despite not having fixed schemas, are rich in information useful for different disciplines. Systems that simply retrieve information are no longer enough. What is needed are approaches that allow the comprehension, synthesis and visualization of complex and extended contents. In this talk, Oriana will describe how Prometeia Data Science team extracts value from unstructured data, combining NLP techniques with other analytical methods such as Deep Learning, from the business point of view. Oriana will analyze 2 different use cases: Ticket automation and Monitoring and forecasting of operational losses.
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/in/oriana-angelucci-92090193/

Agenda of event:
18:30 â€“ 19.15 Welcoming & First talk
19:15 â€“ 20.00 Second Talk
20.00 - 20.45 Aperitivo & Networking

Due to limitations of seats, please RSVP yes, if you are sure can make it else please give the chance to other people who are interested to participate.
Thanks all for your collaboration and looking forward to meet up with all of you!

title: Writing sharable (R) code. Ohâ€¦ and sharing it!
description:
Join this session where we will build an R package, write unit tests for it, push it in a GitHub repository and integrate Travis CI with it!
If time permits, we can discuss briefly at the end how to build a drat repository â€” aimed to host multiple R packages â€” using GitHub as a Web Server, and how to use Travis CI to automatically push updates of your packages into the drat repo.

If you have never created an R package before, you may feel like this is too much information in a just short while. But donâ€™t let this overwhelm you! The aim of this session is to introduce you to the relevant concepts, as we will touch upon the most important of them rather than diving into details. Even if you donâ€™t fully understand what you are doing during the session, you will hopefully leave with a different perspective on how you can organise your code (for yourself or others) and gear up with the needed resources for the next time you want to reproduce these steps more seriously.

Prerequisites:
- Bring your own laptop!
- (Optional) Rstudio installed; this is not necessary to produce R packages but it does make your life easier as the main package for R package development, devtools, is well integrated with RStudio.
- The following R packages:
- devtools, usethis and roxygen2
- tidyverse, rlang
- (optional) drat
- ... if I have forgotten something, we will install it on the spot.
- A GitHub account. I could list this also as optional, but if you want the full experience from this second half of the session, itâ€™s good to reproduce the steps yourself. You are of course welcome either way.
- A travis account (go to travis-ci.com and sign up with GitHub; this prerequisite assumes you already have a GitHub account)

Program:
18.00 Welcome
18.10 Maria Kalimeri, "Writing sharable R code."
19.30 Questions and mingle
20.00 Closing the event

title: R Beginner series: Introduction to dplyr
description:
New Year / New Skills
Let 2019 be a game changing year for you. Come learn R and Data Science skills with us!!

R-Ladies Orlando will be running few sessions for Absolute R Beginners!! There will be a short intro to RStudio and R basics at 7:00, followed by an intro to R for Data Science, using the tidyverse package, specifically dplyr. This is part 3 of the series, but it is still an opportunity for anyone completely new to R to get started.

Bring your (charged) laptop and we'll help you get up and running with the software, walk you through the R programming basics, help with FAQs, point you to relevant learning resources, and any other fundamental R questions you may have!

Please look over our github page for materials from our last workshop (2019-01-23) and see if you can follow through the examples https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_orlando/tree/master/2019-01-23_Workshop

Please make sure you have R and RStudio downloaded ready to go.

To download R, go to https://cloud.r-project.org (https://cloud.r-project.org/)

To download RStudio http://www.rstudio.com/download

Follow the instructions to download and install.

Also please create an account with Kaggle, as we are going to be using a lot of their datasets. I think you can loggin with your gmail, yahoo and even facebook account.

The beginners series will be based on Garrett Grolemund and Hadley Wickham book, "R for Data Science" http://r4ds.had.co.nz/

Tentative schedule:

* Visualization with ggplot2 (End of February)

* Introduction to tidyverse (End of March)

* Data Science with R (End of April)

-Import

-Tidy

-Transform

-Model and Visualize

-Communicate

â€¢ Important to know
Anyone and everyone interested in R/Data Science should join our group and participate/contribute in any way you can, be they learners, teachers, developers or innovators! We encourage women and minority genders to present/lead most sessions, conversations but we have no restrictions whatsoever when it comes to membership, participation, and discussions. So, please join us and bring your R-family & R-friends!

You must adhere to our code of conduct. https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: How to Teach R - Brainstorming
description:
Who is invited?
If you've ever tried learning or teaching R, or were curious but could never start off, we invite you to come share your thoughts with us. If you have resources you use to learn or teach R, you can bring these with you!

What we plan to do?
We hope to gather ideas and resources about (1) what one needs to use R effectively - at different stages of learning, (2) what the members of this group would like to learn, (3) what the members of this groups would like to teach, (4) what ways of learning/teaching R work and what don't.

What we plan to achieve?
By the end of these two hours, we hope to have a collection of resources and concrete monthly workshops that R-Ladies can offer over the next few sessions.

title: R Beginners Workshop 4: Reproducible Research
description:
This workshop will give a small introduction to reproducible research. Attendees will learn how to use R markdown as a way of keeping track of their data cleaning and analysis. You will need access to a laptop, whether it is your own or you are sharing with a colleague. You will also need to download R and RStudio before the workshop (instructions will be sent to your email).

Skill level: beginner to intermediate.

This fourth workshop will be held at ECU Mt Lawley, Room 14.114, Building 14 from 5:45pm on Tuesday 2 April, 2019.

Space is limited for this event so get in quick!

https://www.eventbrite.com.au/e/reproducible-research-with-r-tickets-58419600598

title: #ShutUpandCode
description:
Learning something new on your own is hard! So lets meet up and learn new R things together.

On the first Tuesday of the month, RLadiesSydney will host small meetups where ladies can meet up, shut up (talking is allowed if you are seeking/getting help), and code.

Modelled on the academic writing #ShutUpAndWrite movement (https://thesiswhisperer.com/shut-up-and-write/), the idea is make learning social. The location will move around but you can pencil first Tuesday of month into your calendar.

There are only 10 places available at each session, so ONLY RSVP if you are SURE you will come. Please do not take a place from another RLady, and then not turn up. RSVPs will open 7 days in advance.

Attached is campus map and the shortest routes from train station. Nearest car park is West 3. MUSE is the big red building near the centre of the campus, hard to miss.

title: Tidy Tuesdays with R-Ladies Ames
description: Come join R-Ladies Ames and flex your R skills working on the weekly Tidy Tuesday dataset. This is a weekly event hosted by R for Data Science that emphasizes learning how to clean, tidy, and visualize data "from the wild". Bring your lunch and hack away with us! https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

description:
Dear Rladies,

Spring is here, and the Rladies of Brussels is delighted to host data science enthusiasts to a morning coffee of chats and data science news. It would be great to hear your journey, challenges, and triumphs.

Hope to see you soon!

title: Introduction to R programming + Version control with Git and RStudio
description:
Have you always wanted to learn R but never had the chance to do it by yourself? You learned R a long time ago and want to refresh your knowledge? You have some general idea of what is R and how to use some commands but want to have a solid base? This meetup is for all of you!

If you are already an R guru, our fast talk might interest you: version control with git and RStudio. Because you are not programming unless you git!

PROGRAM
19:00 -- Welcome and presentations

19:10 -- "Version control with git and RStudio", by Maria Noguera (@maria__noguera).
Version control is a vital part of the programming and scripting process. Learn how to do it painlessly with git's integration in Rstudio!

19:20 --" Introduction to R programming", by Natalia Vilor-Tejedor (@natvilortejedor).
We will provide very basic training in preliminary concepts of R programming. R is an open source statistical programming environment that will always be free. It is supported by a worldwide community of statisticians, and generally incorporates the latest developments in statistical methodology. With the knowledge gained in this R-Ladies workshop, you will be ready to undertake your first data analysis. â€‹ Ready to join this amazing community?

MARIA NOGUERA
Maria Noguera is a Nanoscientist and Nanotechnologist (UAB) with a MSc in Omics Data Analysis (UVIC-UCC). She works as an editor at MDPI - Open Access (Multidisciplinarity Digital Publishing Institute). Besides, she collaborates at The Scientists Dating Forum (@SciDating) and Pint of science Barcelona (#Pint19BCN).

NATALIA VILOR-TEJEDOR
Natalia Vilor-Tejedor is a Postdoctoral Research Scientist at the Center for Genomic Regulation (CRG) and BarcelonaBeta Brain Research Center (BBRC). Moreover, Natalia collaborates in teaching activities as an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics at the Autonomous University of Barcelona (UAB), and in the Department of Systems Biology at the University of Vic (UVIC-UCC). She conducted her PhD thesis in the Biomedicine program of Pompeu Fabra University (UPF) at the Barcelona Institute of Global Health (ISGlobal). Her main interests include statistical methods and analytical strategies in Neurogenetics and Imaging Genetics.

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/nat%C3%A0lia-vilor-tejedor-47aa0a66/

REQUIREMENTS
You will need to bring:
- Your own laptop (remember to charge your battery before coming, there are not enough plugs in the room for everyone!).
- R and RStudio installed (https://cran.r-project.org/ and https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/).
- You can install git in your laptop, but it's not mandatory!

Hope to see you all there!

title: R-Ladies Ottawa Launch Event
description:
R-Ladies Ottawa is pleased to announce that we'll be hosting our official launch event! Come enjoy an evening of R-related discussion, and a chance to network with other R-users from across the city on Thursday March 28th, 2019 at SurveyMonkey (200 Laurier Avenue West, main floor).

Feel free to share the event invite with all those who may be interested!

title: Visualise your data with R -- All levels welcome!
description:
We're very excited to announce our next workshop on data visualization!

In this hands-on event, Limor Raviv will teach you how to create effective and beautiful plots using ggplot2, as well as some other neat packages.

You'll learn how to present your raw data in different ways to make the best of your graphs, how to plot your summarized data, and how to visualize your regression models' results.

The workshop will also use R markdown, giving you all a quick refresher on how to use this handy tool!

The full code for the workshop can be found here: https://github.com/Limor-Raviv/Data-Visualization

SCHEDULE
18:30 Doors open
18:45 Intro to Data Visualisation Principles -- Laurel Brehm
19:00 Interactive Data Visualisation workshop -- Limor Raviv
20:30 Event ends

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R Studio installed.
You'll also need to install some packages - you can simply do that on the spot, or if you like you can also set it up in advance (take a look at the code on GitHub for the list of required packages).

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

SPONSORS
A huge thank you to the Gelderland Zuid library for hosting this event!

title: Linear Mixed models on repeated measurement data
description:
(Please, ensure that register to this event at our Eventbrite page https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/linear-mixed-models-on-repeated-measurement-data-tickets-58573204030 , Meetup registration alone won't be valid!).

In this workshop we will be exploring how to use linear mixed models when we have data that repeats over time. These kinds of models are often used in longitudinal studies or with time series data. They are powerful as the used maximum likelihood approximations rather than least squares, meaning they can better handle missing data, and competing models can be compared directly. By the end of the workshop you should have a basic grasp of the linear mixed model, how to specify one, how to compare models and how to plot results.

The workshop is held by Athanasia Monika Mowinckel, or Mo for short, who is a staff scientist at the Center for Lifespan changes in brain and cognition (LCBC: www.oslobrains.no). She has a PhD in psychology, and loves plotting. And cats. She is a co-founder and current head of the R-Ladies Oslo chapter.

Agenda:

6pm - doors open quick intros and hellos from R-Ladies and hosts

6:30ish pm - quick intros and hellos from R-Ladies and hosts

6:40ish pm - workshop starts!!

8:30ish pm - end of workshop!

See you all there!

title: Heatmaps and Pointmaps using ggmap
description:
This workshop, led by Rebecca Henderson, will focus on learning to produce heatmaps and pointmaps using the Google maps platform. Heatmaps can be used to represent population density, per-capita income, social views, and many other geographically important measurements.

There is some prep work to do beforehand if you'd like to actively follow along at the workshop:

This workshop requires an API console key. Using Google Maps to a certain degree is free, but you must enable billing.
Medium wrote a good article explaining the process to help you: https://medium.com/superkoders/ultimate-guide-to-google-maps-d86ad945636a

You'll also need to install the following packages if you don't have them already. You can do this by running the line

install.packages(c("gdata", "tidyverse", "ggmap", "viridis"))

If you have trouble, feel free to reach out to us at ldnont@rladies.org.

See you then! As usual, those who want to head with us to Milos' afterwards are welcome!

title: Deep Dive into basic Machine Learning concepts in R
description:
Hi Everyone! We are very excited to announce our next workshop, a workshop on Machine Learning brought to you by Kelly Pisane, a data scientist at booking.com.

SPECIAL THANKS to Booking for sponsoring our event as part of their generous support and efforts towards a more diverse tech & data science community.

---------------------------------------------------------
17.00 Doors open, welcome, food & drinks

17.30 Introduction to R- Ladies by Janine Khuc
and Introduction to Booking by Lucie de Nooij

17.55 R- Workshop part 1 by Kelly Pisane

18.45- 19.00 Break

19.00- 20.00 Workshop part 2 by Kelly Pisane

20.00- 20.30 Socialising
---------------------------------------------------------

PROGRAMME
Booking.com is one of the world's leading digital travel platforms. However, with millions of customers and partners across the globe comes the challenge of categorising thousands of customer service enquiries on a daily basis.

To meet this challenge, Booking.com data scientists are using customised machine learning techniques. One of these data scientists is Kelly Pisane. Kelly has a PHD in experimental nanoscale magnetism, and was a former research and development scientist in integrity testing for integrated circuits. She will be discussing how Booking.com uses ML to categorise calls, as well as the algorithms in R they use and how performance is evaluated. Kelly will talk about what's happening behind the scenes and the math involved, by keeping it simple and accessible at the same time. The basic classifiers will be covered, applied to datasets and their performance will be evaluated.

Also speaking at the Meet-Up will be Booking.com data scientist and team lead, Lucie de Nooij. In 2017, Lucie was awarded the first-ever internal Booking.com Tech Playmaker Award for her work as a mentor to women in tech throughout the company. She'll be presenting a short introduction to data science and machine learning at Booking.com.

REQUIREMENTS
A basic knowledge of R is required. Bring your own laptop with R, R Studio installed. We will use the packages caret and tidyverse.

CODE OF CONDUCT
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: Starting Your Journey in Data
description:
This meetup is targeted for ladies who wants to pursue career in data.
During meetup, you'll have chance to connect with data experts in-person.

Outline:
- What's R and R-Ladies
- My Experience with R
- Making a Career Out of Data
- Things you can do in R
- Reporting/Visualizations
- Networking & Refreshments

Note: Bring your laptops, so we can do cool things in R.

Requirements:
- Install R: http://bit.ly/installR
- RStudio: http://bit.ly/RStudio16

Come one and bring friends. You'll have interactive learning and networking opportunity.

title: Women in Computing: History and Present
description:
Come join us at our March R-Ladies Meetup!

This month, we'll be celebrating and talking about the trans*, nonbinary, agender, genderqueer and female people who have gone before us and inspired us with their programming prowess.

From Ada Lovelace to current mentors, we encourage you to bring fun stories, book recommendations, advice for mentors and mentees, and your own awesome accomplishments. (Stories and experiences of people of color are especially encouraged!) We'll be breaking out into small groups to share these stories and see where the conversation goes. Please don't feel you have to bring a story to participate; these will be loose, fun, and adaptable groups!

The meeting will wind up with an rstudio::conf watch party, the lecture TBD. Please feel free to reach out if there's a particular topic you're interested in.

Watch this space for further details as we get closer to the date.

title: R and RStudio Introductory Workshop
description:
Hi everyone! The first workshop of 2019 is finally here! This is an introductory workshop to R and RStudio, suitable for those who do not have any experience with R. You will learn how to find your way around RStudio, interact with R, manage your environment and install packages.

You are required to bring your own laptop. Please ensure you have the latest version of R and RStudio installed on your machine. You can download and install the latest version of R from (https://www.r-project.org/) and RStudio from (https://www.rstudio.com/). If you have questions please contact us before the event.

We would like to thank Nous Group for providing the venue for this event.

Please register via the following link:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/r-and-rstudio-intro-for-the-rladies-community-in-brisbane-tickets-58628573642

Since spaces are limited, if you are unable to attend, please advise us asap so others in the waiting list can attend!

Look forward to our first workshop of the year!

title: Data Science Education "Resource Hack Day"
description:
Hi everyone!

On March 27th the Australian Data Science Education Institute are organising the first ever Data Science Education "Resource Hack Day" and we thought many of you may be interested in participating. The event is being hosted in Melbourne between 5pm and 8pm, but will also be streamed online.

The purpose of the event is for people with an interest in Data Science Education to come together and brainstorm ways to support education from prep to year 12. You can find more details of the event here:

https://adsei.org/resources-hack-day/

We will be organizing a REMOTE event here in Sydney, where we will participate in the Hack Day via streaming and discuss potential future workshops for younger students down the road.

This is perfect for anyone who has an interest in learning and teaching data science. It doesn't matter if you are a teacher, researcher, data scientist, or working in industry - all are welcome!

Right now we are trying to get a sense of the number of people who are interested and where would be the best location to hold the event.

So, if you are interested...

1. fill out this google doc by Wednesday (13 March)

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1S754Llv_JDOIVan4Y4L3Ndp7gHiZhwYJ4SD5wfPLHFg/edit?usp=sharing

2. RSVP to this event

thanks!

title: R Package Workshop
description:
Sebastian's workshop will focus on R package development from the ground up. We will cover package structure, set-up, creating functions, documentation, testing, dependencies, sharing the package with others, package vignettes, hex stickers, and other methods. An example package will be developed during the workshop so attendees can follow along and create their own.

Sebastian is a data scientist at Vroom, an ecommerce start-up that focuses on selling used cars that are delivered to your door. Previously, Sebastian was doing research on cancer genomics as a postdoc at Yale University. He has also been a strong advocate for R-Ladies and is an experienced CRAN package author.

Emily Zabor and Erin Grand are also going to be serving has TAs for this workshop.

Erin Grand works as a Data Scientist at Uncommon Schools where she maintains two R packages. Prior to Uncommon, she worked as a Data Scientist at Crisis Text Line and a software programmer at NASA. In the past, Erin researched star formation and taught introductory courses in astronomy and physics.

title: Intro to R Markdown - easy integration of text, code, references, & more
description: Kristen Sauby will introduce the basics of R Markdown, talk about how it's great for the integration of text and code, is very flexible in terms of formatting, and is a great way to automatically number tables and figures and build a list of reference cited. No prior knowledge of R Markdown is necessary, and we'll have tips and tricks for those of all skill levels.

venues.name: Headquarters Library | Alachua County Library District

title: R-Ladies Chicago welcomes Mara Averick: Sustainers of the Tidyverse
description:
Join us in welcoming tidyverse developer advocate and Twitter #rstats star Mara Averick!

â€¢ What we'll do:

Schedule:
5:45-6 -- R tour for beginners; sign up here: https://tinyurl.com/rladiestour
6-6:30 -- Food, Intros & Announcements
6:30-7:10 -- Talk by Mara
7:10-8:00 -- Socializing/Networking/Hanging out

Bio: Mara Averick is the tidyverse developer advocate at RStudio. She got into R by way of a long-time love for the NBA and (fantasy) basketball. When not catering to the every whim of her dogs, she can be found: perusing weird words; indulging her bibliomania; and/or watching, quantifying, and visualizing Archer.

Topic: Sustainers of the Tidyverse
Abstract: If a piece of open-source software is to survive its own success, it must have a healthy community of active contributors. The tidyverse, a collection of R packages for data science with a shared underlying design philosophy, has become popular in no small part because of its usability among those who do not consider themselves to be â€œprogrammers.â€ However, this active base of non-developer users has been a fruitful source of contributions as weâ€™ve sought to highlight aspects of contributing to open source beyond committing lines of code. This talk will cover the technical tools, virtual spaces, and social norms that have enabled and empowered community contributions.

Find Mara on Twitter: https://twitter.com/dataandme

Q: Are men welcome to attend this event?
A: Our primary mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. ***As such, we strongly encourage that all men who attend this event have a female or non-binary sponsor, as spots may be limited. Please contact chicago@rladies.org if you have questions.***

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

Thank you to Uptake for hosting us!

â€¢ What to bring
Laptop or notebook if you can! Wifi is available and live-tweeting is encouraged.

â€¢ Important to know
We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: R-Ladies for PAWS (Community Data Project Finale)
description:
Join us in March for a celebration of our community data project!

Since February, we have been running a virtual "datathon" to help PAWS (the city's largest no-kill shelter) with data analytics to help them further improve their adoption and foster programs. For more information, check out the February meetup and the project on GitHub (https://github.com/rladiesPHL/2019_datathon).

At this finale event, we will reconvene for the grand conclusion, and to share our experiences with the process. Participating teams will share their work and results.

This event is open to everyone (you don't need to have attended the February event or participated in the datathon). If you are curious about what R can do, or what data science is, then this is a great event to check out!

---
What to bring:
* If you participated in the datathon, organizers will be coordinating with teams to present their projects and results.
* Pizza and soda will be available at 6

---
Getting there:
This event is hosted by Drexel LeBow College of Business at 3220 Market Street. Once you enter LeBow Hall, take the elevators to the 7th floor. We are in the Hindelang Colloquium Room (room 722) on the east side of the building.

title: Taller de R para Principiantes (Â¡Hola, 2019!)
description:
Â¡Vamos a darle la bienvenida a 2019, aprendiendo R! Esta vez, vamos ha realizar un Taller de R para Ciencia de Datos, desde cero y para todos los niveles usando Tidyverse.

:: CRONOGRAMA ::
> 16:30hs a 17:00hs - OrganizaciÃ³n. Deben llevar sus propias computadoras, ubicarse y estar listos. Empezamos muy puntuales.
> 17:00hs a 18:15hs - Taller Parte I
> 18:15hs a 18:30hs - Coffee Break y socializaciÃ³n
> 18:30hs a 19:30hs - Taller Parte II

:: CARACTERÃSTICAS DEL TALLER ::
> Basado en el libro de "R For Data Science", el cual es de acceso gratuito (https://r4ds.had.co.nz/).
> TendrÃ¡n que llevar sus propias computadoras, con R y RStudio instalado. Pueden usar el siguiente tutorial: (https://tinyurl.com/TutorialInstalacionR)
> HabrÃ¡ ejercicios de "tarea" que podrÃ¡n completar en sus casas con tranquilidad, para seguir practicando.

:: PÃšBLICO ::
El taller estarÃ¡ orientado a empezar desde cero. Sin embargo, si ya conoces algo de R estÃ¡s invitado a venir a repasar, y tambiÃ©n a ayudar. EstarÃ­a muy bueno que miembros de R-Ladies Santa Fe que ya tengan experiencia se sumen al Taller y ayuden a responder consultas y problemas que surjan durante el mismo. Cualquier consulta que tengan, con la instalaciÃ³n o con los ejercicios la vemos por el Slack (las que aÃºn no tienen acceso al Slack, pueden enviarnos un mail a santafe@rladies.org).

:: SEDE ::
Queremos agradecerle a la Dra Milagros GutiÃ©rrez, directora del Departamento de IngenierÃ­a en Sistemas de InformaciÃ³n de la UTN FRSF, por ayudarnos a coordinar el encuentro y obtener la ubicaciÃ³n.

title: Tidy Tuesdays with R-Ladies Ames
description: Come join R-Ladies Ames and flex your R skills working on the weekly Tidy Tuesday dataset. This is a weekly event hosted by R for Data Science that emphasizes learning how to clean, tidy, and visualize data "from the wild". Bring your lunch and hack away with us! https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday
